repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Greater Mekong Subregion Power
            Trade Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Greater Mekong Subregion
            Power Trade Project for Cambodia were as follows: outcomes
            not applicable; risk to development outcome was also not
            applicable; Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory;
            and borrower performance was also moderately unsatisfactory.
            A two-year closing date extension was included in the Royal
            Government of Cambodia's (RGC's) official
            restructuring request in August 2010. Initially, the Bank
            informed RGC that it would confirm the project restructuring
            only if the implementing agency could demonstrate concrete
            progress in preparing the new 230 kV transmission line
            (notably processing the necessary procurement that would
            ensure project completion by December 31, 2013). In June
            2011, Bank management informed Electricite du Cambodge (EDC)
            that the RGC's request for project
            restructuring-including the closing date extension and a
            change in the project development objective to remove
            reference to Vietnam-could not be processed due to country
            program conditions. Without the two year extension of the
            closing date, EDC could not proceed with International
            Competitive Bidding (ICB) procurement for the supply and
            installation of the 230 kV line because it could not afford
            to self-finance the associated works. EDC would also suffer
            huge financial losses if it did finance the line and then
            Lao PDR was unable to meet the agreed schedule. Seeing no
            viable options, RGC requested a full cancellation of the
            grant for this project on October 4, 2011.

repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Greater Mekong Subregion Power
            Trade Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement plan for Cambodia
            Greater Mekong sub-region power trade project looks at
            compensation rates for the various categories in which
            reimbursement will be provided have been based on the
            replacement cost conducted by the independent organization,
            SBK Research and Development, along National Road No. 7 from
            Kratie-Stung Treng to the Laos-Cambodia Border. All affected
            shops or businesses will be compensated at full replacement
            cost depend on types of structures without deduction for
            depreciation or salvageable materials for affected
            structures and other fixed assets. Disruption allowance
            during a relocation period will be provided of US$ 40 or the
            equivalent of 40kg of rice per household for businesses that
            will be required to close down during the relocation period.
            Loss of business income will be provided in lump sum amounts
            of $40 per small shops while big businesses have to provide
            their business income statement. For employees, cash
            compensation will be provided for lost wages for each day
            they cannot work while a business is reorganizing at new site.

repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Greater Mekong Subregion Power
            Trade Projects : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The purpose of these Greater Mekong
            Sub-region Power Trade Projects is to: 1) Identify and
            assess environmental impacts associated with transmission
            lines; 2) Identify design, construction and maintenance
            measures to avoid or mitigate potential adverse
            environmental impacts, to be incorporated into the final
            design; 3) Develop an environmental management plan and
            associated monitoring plan for project construction and
            operation; and 4) Assess the organizational capacity of the
            implementing agency and provide recommendations for
            enhancement. In addition, the objective of the Detailed
            Environmental Management plan (DEMP) is to determine the
            necessary practical mitigation measures for avoiding, and/or
            minimizing negative impacts caused by the Project. This
            project has a number of potential negative impacts
            including: a) Land acquisition; b) Disruption of farming
            activities and the disturbance of crops, bunds, canals and
            drains; c) Wildlife will be affected by transmission line
            construction and operation through the loss of habitat from
            vegetation clearing; d) Exhaust emissions from machinery
            used for tower and substation construction will be minor,
            localized and of short duration; e) soil erosion and water
            pollution. Different mitigating approaches could be
            considered for some of the negative impacts, depending on
            the timing of the Project.

repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia and Lao, PDR - Greater Mekong
            Subregion Power Trade Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Greater Mekong
            Sub-region Power Trade Projects is to enhance power trade
            within Greater Mekong Sub-Region (GMS) with a view to also
            bringing affordable grid-based electricity to selected
            provinces in Cambodia through import of power from Lao PDR
            and Vietnam. Overall, the Project has the following main
            components: Component 1: Development of cross-border 115 kV
            Transmission Line linking Lao PDR (Ban Hat) and Cambodia
            (Stung Treng) to facilitate import of lower cost electricity
            from Lao PDR to displace higher cost diesel-fueled
            generation sources in Cambodia; Component 2: Development of
            cross-border 115 kV Transmission Line linking Vietnam (Tan
            Bien) and Cambodia (Kampong Cham) for bilateral power
            exchanges, beginning with imports of lower cost electricity
            from Vietnam to displace diesel-fueled generation in
            Cambodia, and leading over the long term to the transfer of
            surplus hydropower from Cambodia to Vietnam; Component 3:
            Development of the Xeset 1 to Saravan segment of the
            proposed 115 kV Transmission Link that would eventually
            interconnect electricity grids from (western) Thailand
            through (southern) Laos to (southern) Cambodia; Component 4:
            Development (feasibility, design, building, commissioning)
            of a modern Load Dispatch Center (LDC) for Lao PDR to
            facilitate regional power trade. An LDC, from a regional
            perspective, is essential for bringing: (i) voltage and
            frequency control; (ii) system protection and reliability;
            and (iii) technical information on exchange and dispatching,
            up to the minimum standards required for security of the
            grids in neighboring countries that are connected, or will
            be connected, to Electricite du Laos (EdL's) system. By
            doing so, development of grid-to-grid interconnections and
            the security of a future integrated GMS power grid would be
            enhanced; and Component 5: TA activities in support of: (i)
            development, through a regional perspective, of feasibility
            study for hydropower generation for facilitating regional
            power trade; (ii) consulting services for project
            implementation; and (iii) consulting services for
            institutional strengthening.
